GLRT-Optimal Noncoherent Lattice Decoding

Daniel J. Ryan†‡∗,  Iain B. Collings‡  and  I. Vaughan L. Clarkson⋆ 
I. V. L. Clarkson was on study leave throughout 2005 at the Dept. of Electrical & Computer Engineering, University of British Columbia, Canada. This paper has appeared in part at VTC-Spring 2006 and ICASSP 2006. †School of Electrical and Information Engineering, University of Sydney, Australia,
Phone: +612 9372 4465, Fax: +612 9372 4490, Email: dan@ee.usyd.edu.au
‡Wireless Technologies Laboratory, CSIRO ICT Centre, Australia,
Phone: +612 9372 4120, Fax: +612 9372 4490, Email: iain.collings@csiro.au
⋆School of Information Technology and Electrical Engineering, University of Queensland, Australia,

Abstract

This paper presents new low-complexity lattice-decoding algorithms for noncoherent block detection of QAM and PAM signals over complex-valued fading channels. The algorithms are optimal in terms of the generalized likelihood ratio test (GLRT). The computational complexity is polynomial in the block length; making GLRT-optimal noncoherent detection feasible for implementation. We also provide even lower complexity suboptimal algorithms. Simulations show that the suboptimal algorithms have performance indistinguishable from the optimal algorithms. Finally, we consider block based transmission, and propose to use noncoherent detection as an alternative to pilot assisted transmission (PAT). The new technique is shown to outperform PAT.

Index Terms:
Noncoherent detection, lattice decoding, wireless communications.

I Introduction

Noncoherent transmission of digital signals over unknown fading channels has recently received significant attention especially for the case of the block-fading channel model. Applications include recovery from deep fades in pilot-symbol assisted modulation based schemes, eavesdropping, and non-data-aided channel estimation. Noncoherent transmission is particularly applicable to systems exhibiting small coherence intervals where the use of training signals would result in a significant loss in throughput. Recently, some elegant information-theoretic results have been derived for noncoherent single and multiple-antenna systems under the assumption of Rayleigh fading, for example [1, 2]. Information theoretic aspects of noncoherent transmission were considered in [3] which concluded that at low SNR and for small coherence intervals there is a significant capacity penalty by using training. Under this noncoherent detection regime, it has been shown by numerical simulation that standard modulation techniques such as quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) can achieve near-capacity in the single-antenna noncoherent block Rayleigh-fading channel [4].

This paper focuses on noncoherent receiver design for the block fading channel. A great deal of work has been performed on partially coherent receivers such as pilot-symbol assisted modulation (PSAM) [5, 6], per-survivor techniques [7], and coupled estimators [8]. However the challenge remains to develop high-performance, low-complexity, fully noncoherent receivers.

Various suboptimal algorithms have been proposed for block-based noncoherent detection. For slowly fading channels, a blind phase recovery approach was proposed in [9] for noncoherent detection of differentially encoded QAM [10] where the attenuation was assumed to be known exactly at the receiver. In [11], a suboptimal technique for PSK was proposed which involved forming a number of equally spaced channel phase estimates. An extension to multi-amplitude constellations was also presented, where every sequence of symbol amplitudes is considered, and then the PSK technique is applied to determine the phase of the symbols. Unfortunately, the complexity of this suboptimal approach is still exponential in the sequence length, albeit with a smaller base.

Recently, lattice decoding algorithms have been applied to noncoherent and differential detection. For PSK over temporally-correlated Rayleigh fading channels, a form of lattice decoding (namely sphere-decoding) can be applied since it turns out that the detection metric is Euclidean [12]. Lattice decoding techniques have also been used for differential detection of diagonal space-time block codes over Rayleigh fading channels, by approximating the decision metric with a Euclidean metric [13, 14]. In [15], we presented simulation results for another lattice projection approach for suboptimal PAM and QAM detection. Unfortunately, each of these algorithms require complexity exponential with the block length to guarantee that the optimal estimate is found [16, 17]. Practical implementation considerations demand that low complexity algorithms be developed.

For the case of the constant envelope PSK constellation, a detection algorithm with complexity O​(T​log⁡T)𝑂𝑇𝑇O(T\log T) was developed in [18, 19] (where T𝑇T is the block length), which can provide the optimal data estimate over an unknown noncoherent fading channel, in terms of the Generalized Likelihood Ratio Test (GLRT). The GLRT is equivalent to joint ML estimation of a continuous valued channel parameter and discrete-valued data parameters. This approach was generalized in [20], where they outlined a general graph-based approach which involved forming a spanning tree. Specific details were presented for the cases of QAM over a phase noncoherent channel (i.e. known channel amplitude) [20, 21], and for PSK over a fading channel with coding [22]. The challenge remains to develop efficient algorithms for optimal noncoherent sequence detection of multi-amplitude constellations over fading channels.

In this paper we propose a new GLRT-optimal noncoherent lattice decoding approach for QAM and PAM symbols which has complexity polynomial in the block length. We start by considering detection of M𝑀M-ary PAM over real-valued fading channels (which we shall term real-PAM). We show that the GLRT-optimal codeword estimate is the closest codeword (or lattice point) in angle to the line described by the received vector. We propose an algorithm that searches along the line, and chooses the best codeword estimate from this search. We provide a theorem that bounds the search to a segment of the line, limiting the number of codewords that need to be considered. We show how the search can be done in an iterative manner, and that the resulting complexity of the algorithm is O​(T​log⁡T)𝑂𝑇𝑇O(T\log T).

We then consider the more practical case of M𝑀M-ary QAM detection over complex-valued fading channels, and show that in this case the GLRT-optimal codeword estimate is the closest codeword in angle to a plane described by the received vector. We propose an algorithm that searches across the plane, and chooses the best codeword estimate from this search. We provide a theorem that bounds the search to a segment of the plane. We show how the extent of the search can be further reduced by exploiting the rotational symmetry of the constellation. The resulting plane search algorithm can be performed with complexity of order O​(T3)𝑂superscript𝑇3O(T^{3}).

We also present new suboptimal noncoherent QAM detection algorithms with even lower complexity; by combining a channel phase estimator with our fast real-PAM algorithm. We propose using O​(T)𝑂𝑇O(T) instances of the real-PAM algorithm. This approach therefore has complexity of order O​(T2​log⁡T)𝑂superscript𝑇2𝑇O(T^{2}\log T). Simulations indicate that there is a negligible performance loss compared to GLRT, when using this suboptimal technique.

Finally, we also propose a pilot-assisted version of our new reduced-search noncoherent lattice-decoding algorithms. The pilot symbol is used to remove the ambiguities inherent with noncoherent detection. Our approach obtains improved performance compared with standard pilot assisted transmission [6], while maintaining the same data rate.

II System Model

II-A Signal Model

We define a codebook 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T) as the set of all possible sequences of T𝑇T transmitted symbols, 𝐱=[x1,…,xT]′𝐱superscriptsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑇′\mathbf{x}=[x_{1},\ldots,x_{T}]^{\prime}, such that each xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} is in some constellation 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. For an M𝑀M-ary PAM constellation, 𝒳={±1,±3,…,±(M−1)}𝒳plus-or-minus1plus-or-minus3…plus-or-minus𝑀1\mathcal{X}={\left\{\pm 1,\pm 3,\ldots,\pm(M-1)\right\}}. For QAM, 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} is a subset of the Gaussian (complex) integers with odd real and imaginary components. For example, for an M2superscript𝑀2M^{2}-ary square QAM constellation, 𝒳={x|Re⁡{x}∈𝒳′,Im⁡{x}∈𝒳′}𝒳conditional-set𝑥formulae-sequenceRe𝑥superscript𝒳′Im𝑥superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}={\left\{\;x\;|\operatorname{Re}{\left\{x\right\}}\in\mathcal{X}^{\prime},\;\operatorname{Im}{\left\{x\right\}}\in\mathcal{X}^{\prime}\right\}} where 𝒳′≜{±1,±3,…,±(M−1)}≜superscript𝒳′plus-or-minus1plus-or-minus3…plus-or-minus𝑀1\mathcal{X}^{\prime}\triangleq{\left\{\pm 1,\pm 3,\ldots,\pm(M-1)\right\}}. Thus each codebook 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T) is a set of lattice points drawn from a subset of the unit lattice of ℝTsuperscriptℝ𝑇\mathbb{R}^{T} or ℂTsuperscriptℂ𝑇\mathbb{C}^{T}.

We consider block fading channels and assume that the channel hℎh is constant for at least T𝑇T symbols as in [4, 2, 3, 1, 11]. We will consider narrowband fading channels where hℎh is either real-valued and complex-valued channels. Thus we can write the received codeword 𝐲=[y1,…,yT]′𝐲superscriptsubscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑇′\mathbf{y}=[\;y_{1},\ldots,y_{T}\;]^{\prime} as follows,

𝐲=h​𝐱+𝐧𝐲ℎ𝐱𝐧\mathbf{y}=h\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{n} (1)

where 𝐧=[n1,…,nT]′𝐧superscriptsubscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑇′\mathbf{n}=[\;n_{1},\ldots,n_{T}\;]^{\prime} is a vector of additive white Gaussian noise.

II-B Detection

The noncoherent detection problem is to estimate 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} based on 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} without knowledge of the channel and in the absence of training data. The log-likelihood function of the maximum likelihood (ML) detector (of both channel and data) is given by

L​(𝐲;𝐱,h)=−‖𝐲−h​𝐱‖2𝐿𝐲𝐱ℎsuperscriptnorm𝐲ℎ𝐱2{L}{\left(\mathbf{y};\mathbf{x},h\right)}=-\left\|\mathbf{y}-h\mathbf{x}\right\|^{2} (2)

where constant factors have been discarded and ∥⋅∥\left\|\cdot\right\| represents the Euclidean norm. For a given codeword hypothesis 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}}, the likelihood function is maximized by choosing

h^=𝐱^†​𝐲‖𝐱^‖2^ℎsuperscript^𝐱†𝐲superscriptnorm^𝐱2\smash{\hat{h}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\dagger}\mathbf{y}}{\left\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\|^{2}} (3)

where (⋅)†superscript⋅†(\cdot)^{\dagger} denotes Hermitian transpose.

Hence, the ML estimate of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} conditioned on the corresponding channel estimate, is given by

𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} =arg⁡max𝐱^∈𝒞​(𝒳,T)⁡L​(𝐲;𝐱^,𝐱^†​𝐲‖𝐱^‖2)absentsubscript^𝐱𝒞𝒳𝑇𝐿𝐲^𝐱superscript^𝐱†𝐲superscriptnorm^𝐱2\displaystyle=\arg\max_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T)}L\left(\mathbf{y};\hat{\mathbf{x}},\frac{\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\dagger}\mathbf{y}}{\left\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\|^{2}}\right)
=arg⁡max𝐱^∈𝒞​(𝒳,T)⁡|𝐱^†​𝐲|2‖𝐱^‖2absentsubscript^𝐱𝒞𝒳𝑇superscriptsuperscript^𝐱†𝐲2superscriptnorm^𝐱2\displaystyle=\arg\max_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T)}\frac{{\left|\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\dagger}\mathbf{y}\right|}^{2}}{\left\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\|^{2}} (4)

This is the Generalized Likelihood Ratio Test (GLRT) [23] considered in [11, 20].

Note that (4) is equivalently given by

𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} =arg⁡max𝐱^∈𝒞​(𝒳,T)⁡|𝐱^†​𝐲|2‖𝐱^‖2​‖𝐲‖2absentsubscript^𝐱𝒞𝒳𝑇superscriptsuperscript^𝐱†𝐲2superscriptnorm^𝐱2superscriptnorm𝐲2\displaystyle=\arg\max_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T)}\frac{{\left|\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\dagger}\mathbf{y}\right|}^{2}}{\left\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\|^{2}\left\|\mathbf{y}\right\|^{2}} (5)
=arg⁡max𝐱^∈𝒞​(𝒳,T)⁡cos2⁡θ​(𝐱^,𝐲)absentsubscript^𝐱𝒞𝒳𝑇superscript2𝜃^𝐱𝐲\displaystyle=\arg\max_{\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T)}\cos^{2}\theta(\hat{\mathbf{x}},\mathbf{y}) (6)

where θ​(𝐱,𝐲)𝜃𝐱𝐲\theta(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}) is the principal angle between 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} [24]. Thus 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} can be found by searching the points of 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T) to find the one closest in angle to 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}.

For QAM, we can also obtain a geometric interpretation of (4) by expressing the complex vectors in ℝ2​Tsuperscriptℝ2𝑇\mathbb{R}^{2T}. We will use the underscore notation 𝐱¯¯𝐱\mathbf{\underline{x}} to denote the mapped version of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} as follows,

𝐱¯=[Re⁡{x1}​Im⁡{x1}​…​Re⁡{xT}​Im⁡{xT}]′¯𝐱superscriptdelimited-[]Resubscript𝑥1Imsubscript𝑥1…Resubscript𝑥𝑇Imsubscript𝑥𝑇′\mathbf{\underline{x}}=[\;\operatorname{Re}{\left\{x_{1}\right\}}\;\operatorname{Im}{\left\{x_{1}\right\}}\;\ldots\;\operatorname{Re}{\left\{x_{T}\right\}}\;\operatorname{Im}{\left\{x_{T}\right\}}]^{\prime} (7)

and denote the real-valued codebook as 𝒞R​(𝒳,T)={𝐱¯|𝐱∈𝒞}subscript𝒞𝑅𝒳𝑇conditional-set¯𝐱𝐱𝒞\mathcal{C}_{R}(\mathcal{X},T)={\left\{\mathbf{\underline{x}}\;|\;\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{C}\right\}}. For M2superscript𝑀2M^{2}-ary square QAM, we therefore have 𝒞R​(𝒳,T)=𝒞​(𝒳′,2​T)subscript𝒞𝑅𝒳𝑇𝒞superscript𝒳′2𝑇\mathcal{C}_{R}(\mathcal{X},T)=\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X}^{\prime},2T) where 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}^{\prime} is an M𝑀M-ary PAM constellation. We also define 𝐘¯∈ℝ2​T×2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2𝑇2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{2T\times 2} as a basis for the subspace 𝐲​ℂ𝐲ℂ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{C} mapped into the real space ℝ2​Tsuperscriptℝ2𝑇\mathbb{R}^{2T}; that is

𝐘¯¯𝐘\displaystyle\mathbf{\underline{Y}} ≜[Re⁡{y1}Im⁡{y1}…Re⁡{yT}Im⁡{yT}−Im⁡{y1}Re⁡{y1}…−Im⁡{yT}Re⁡{yT}]′.≜absentsuperscriptdelimited-[]matrixResubscript𝑦1Imsubscript𝑦1…Resubscript𝑦𝑇Imsubscript𝑦𝑇Imsubscript𝑦1Resubscript𝑦1…Imsubscript𝑦𝑇Resubscript𝑦𝑇′\displaystyle\triangleq{\left[\begin{matrix}\;\;\;\operatorname{Re}{\left\{y_{1}\right\}}&\operatorname{Im}{\left\{y_{1}\right\}}&\ldots&\;\;\;\operatorname{Re}{\left\{y_{T}\right\}}&\operatorname{Im}{\left\{y_{T}\right\}}\\ -\operatorname{Im}{\left\{y_{1}\right\}}&\operatorname{Re}{\left\{y_{1}\right\}}&\ldots&-\operatorname{Im}{\left\{y_{T}\right\}}&\operatorname{Re}{\left\{y_{T}\right\}}\end{matrix}\right]}^{\prime}. (8)

Note that the columns of 𝐘¯¯𝐘\mathbf{\underline{Y}} are orthogonal. The projection matrix 𝐏​(𝐲)∈ℝ2​T×2​T𝐏𝐲superscriptℝ2𝑇2𝑇\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{y})\in\mathbb{R}^{2T\times 2T} is defined as

𝐏​(𝐲)≜𝐘¯​𝐘¯′‖𝐲‖2≜𝐏𝐲¯𝐘superscript¯𝐘′superscriptnorm𝐲2\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{y})\triangleq\frac{\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\,\mathbf{\underline{Y}}^{\prime}}{\left\|\mathbf{y}\right\|^{2}} (9)

such that

𝐏​(𝐲)​𝐱¯=arg⁡min𝐯¯∈𝐘¯​ℝ2⁡‖𝐱¯−𝐯¯‖.𝐏𝐲¯𝐱subscript¯𝐯¯𝐘superscriptℝ2norm¯𝐱¯𝐯\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{y})\mathbf{\underline{x}}=\arg\min_{\mathbf{\underline{v}}\in\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2}}\left\|\mathbf{\underline{x}}-\mathbf{\underline{v}}\right\|.

That is, the vector 𝐏​(𝐲)​𝐱¯𝐏𝐲¯𝐱\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{y})\mathbf{\underline{x}} is the projection of 𝐱¯¯𝐱\mathbf{\underline{x}} onto the subspace 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2}. Now, it can be easily shown that

𝐱¯^opt=arg⁡max𝐱¯^:𝐱^∈𝒞​(𝒳,T)⁡cos2⁡θ​(𝐱¯^,𝐏​(𝐲)​𝐱¯^)superscript¯^𝐱optsubscript:^¯𝐱^𝐱𝒞𝒳𝑇superscript2𝜃^¯𝐱𝐏𝐲^¯𝐱\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}^{\text{opt}}=\arg\max_{\hat{\mathbf{\underline{x}}}:\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T)}\cos^{2}\theta(\hat{\mathbf{\underline{x}}},\mathbf{P}(\mathbf{y})\hat{\mathbf{\underline{x}}})

Thus the GLRT-optimal data estimate 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}, corresponds to the 𝐱¯^∈𝒞R​(𝒳,T)^¯𝐱subscript𝒞𝑅𝒳𝑇\hat{\mathbf{\underline{x}}}\in\mathcal{C}_{R}(\mathcal{X},T) closest in angle to the plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2}.

It is important to note that two forms of ambiguity exist for this noncoherent detection problem. The first is the well-known phase ambiguity which occurs for any constellation that is invariant to a particular phase rotation. For example, for square QAM constellations the following four optimal channel estimate and codeword pairs have the same likelihood: (h^opt,𝐱^opt)superscript^ℎoptsuperscript^𝐱opt(\smash{\hat{h}}^{\text{opt}},\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}), (−h^opt,−𝐱^opt)superscript^ℎoptsuperscript^𝐱opt(-\smash{\hat{h}}^{\text{opt}},-\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}), (−i​h^opt,i​𝐱^opt)𝑖superscript^ℎopt𝑖superscript^𝐱opt(-i\smash{\hat{h}}^{\text{opt}},i\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}) and (i​h^opt,−i​𝐱^opt)𝑖superscript^ℎopt𝑖superscript^𝐱opt(i\smash{\hat{h}}^{\text{opt}},-i\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}); corresponding to the four π/2𝜋2\pi/2 rotations of the constellation. We will assume that this type of ambiguity can be resolved, for example, by using the phase of the last symbol from the previous codeword [4], or by using differential encoding [10]. The second type of ambiguity we call a divisor ambiguity and arises when there are multiple points in 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T) that lie on the same 1-dimensional (real or complex) subspace e.g. [1,1,1]111[1,1,1] and [3,3,3]333[3,3,3] for 4-ary real-PAM with T=3𝑇3T=3. This produces a lower bound on the noncoherent block detection error rate as discussed and analyzed in [25].

III Reduced Search Space

In this section we show that the GLRT-optimal data estimate 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}, can be found without testing all the elements of 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T). In the previous section we established that 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} is the codeword closest in angle to a particular subspace, so it naturally makes sense to define a ‘nearest neighbor set’ of the subspace and search within that set. The subspace of interest has basis vector 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} and passes through the origin. We show that the nearest neighbor set for this subspace contains 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}. This implies that low complexity decoding algorithms can be developed, based on finding this particular nearest neighbor set, and searching it.

Definition 1

We define N​N​(𝐯)𝑁𝑁𝐯NN(\mathbf{v}) to be the point, or set of points, in 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T) closest to the arbitrary point 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} (i.e., the nearest neighbor to 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}). That is, 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d} is an element of N​N​(𝐯)𝑁𝑁𝐯NN(\mathbf{v}) if ‖𝐯−𝐝‖⩽‖𝐯−𝐳‖norm𝐯𝐝norm𝐯𝐳\left\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{d}\right\|\leqslant\left\|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{z}\right\| for all 𝐳∈𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝐳𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathbf{z}\in\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T).

Of course, usually N​N​(𝐯)𝑁𝑁𝐯NN(\mathbf{v}) will have a single element, and in this case we can write N​N​(𝐯)=𝐝𝑁𝑁𝐯𝐝NN(\mathbf{v})=\mathbf{d}.

Definition 2

We define 𝒩​(𝒞​(𝒳,T),𝐲)𝒩𝒞𝒳𝑇𝐲\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T),\mathbf{y}) to be the nearest neighbor subset of the codebook 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T), corresponding to the subspace with basis vector 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}, passing through the origin. That is, 𝐮∈𝒩​(𝒞​(𝒳,T),𝐲)𝐮𝒩𝒞𝒳𝑇𝐲\mathbf{u}\in{\mathcal{N}}{\left(\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T),\mathbf{y}\right)} if and only if there exists some λ𝜆\lambda such that N​N​(λ​𝐲)=𝐮𝑁𝑁𝜆𝐲𝐮NN(\lambda\mathbf{y})=\mathbf{u}.

Note that from a geometrical perspective, it is useful to think of λ𝜆\lambda as being equivalent to the inverse of a channel estimate; implying that a point 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} is in the nearest neighbor set if there is a channel estimate h^^ℎ\hat{h} such that the distance |𝐲−h^​𝐮|𝐲^ℎ𝐮|\mathbf{y}-\hat{h}\mathbf{u}| is smaller than for any other point. Consequently we define λ^opt≜(h^opt)−1≜superscript^𝜆optsuperscriptsuperscript^ℎopt1\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}\triangleq(\smash{\hat{h}}^{\text{opt}})^{-1} as the reciprocal of the optimal channel estimate.

The following property of the GLRT-optimal codeword estimate 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}, allows us to reduce the set of codewords which need to be tested, to a small subset of the |𝒳|Tsuperscript𝒳𝑇{\left|\mathcal{X}\right|}^{T} possible codewords (where |⋅|{\left|\cdot\right|} denotes set cardinality). Note that an equivalent result was presented in [20], however the geometrical interpretation of our formulation is more apparent; and is important when developing our new search algorithms later.

Property 1
𝐱^opt∈𝒩​(𝒞​(𝒳,T),𝐲).superscript^𝐱opt𝒩𝒞𝒳𝑇𝐲\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}\in\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T),\mathbf{y}).
Proof:

Consider the case where 𝐱^opt∉𝒩​(𝒞​(𝒳,T),𝐲)superscript^𝐱opt𝒩𝒞𝒳𝑇𝐲\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}\notin\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T),\mathbf{y}). From Definition 2 this implies that there exists some 𝐱^∈𝒩​(𝒞​(𝒳,T),𝐲)^𝐱𝒩𝒞𝒳𝑇𝐲\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T),\mathbf{y}) such that ‖λ^opt​𝐲−𝐱^‖<‖λ^opt​𝐲−𝐱^opt‖normsuperscript^𝜆opt𝐲^𝐱normsuperscript^𝜆opt𝐲superscript^𝐱opt||\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}\mathbf{y}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}||<||\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}\mathbf{y}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}|| however this would imply L​(𝐲;𝐱^,h^opt)>L​(𝐲;𝐱^opt,h^opt)𝐿𝐲^𝐱superscript^ℎopt𝐿𝐲superscript^𝐱optsuperscript^ℎoptL(\mathbf{y};\hat{\mathbf{x}},\smash{\hat{h}}^{\text{opt}})>L(\mathbf{y};\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}},\smash{\hat{h}}^{\text{opt}}) from (2) and hence we have a proof by contradiction. ∎

IV PAM Detection For Real-Valued Fading Channels

This section presents a low complexity algorithm for GLRT-optimal noncoherent PAM detection over real-valued channels. Practically, such channels arise in baseband transmission (eg. multi-level PCM), or in certain bandpass systems where phase and frequency are separately estimated by a phase-locked loop.

We first present a theorem that we will use to reduce the number of codewords that need to be examined, even beyond the limitations imposed by Property 1. Note that in this real-valued channel case, the subspace of interest (defined by 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}) actually reduces to a line, 𝐲​ℝ𝐲ℝ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{R}. The theorem implies that only a limited extent of the line needs to be searched; and that the extent depends on the largest value of 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}. We then propose a fast low-complexity iterative algorithm to perform the search. In the sequel, we will extend the algorithm to complex-valued channels. Later, we will directly incorporate the algorithm from this section into an extremely low complexity suboptimal algorithm for noncoherent detection over the more commonly encountered complex-valued channels.

IV-A Limiting the Search Space

For noncoherent detection of M𝑀M-ary PAM codewords of length T𝑇T over a real-valued fading channel

|λ^opt​yt|⩽M+T−2superscript^𝜆optsubscript𝑦𝑡𝑀𝑇2{\left|\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}y_{t}\right|}\leqslant M+T-2

for all t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,\ldots,T.

IV-B PAM Algorithm

In this Section we use Property 1 and Theorem 1 to develop a low-complexity algorithm for real-PAM detection. This algorithm reduces the number of codewords for which the decision metric is evaluated to order M​T𝑀𝑇MT, which is much smaller than the set of all possible MTsuperscript𝑀𝑇M^{T} codewords that would be considered by an exhaustive search. Furthermore, we demonstrate how the algorithm can be implemented in an iterative manner so that the complexity is O​(T​log⁡T)𝑂𝑇𝑇O(T\log T).

Property 1 implies that 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} can be found by calculating the metric in (4) for only those 𝐱^∈𝒩​(𝒞​(𝒳,T),𝐲)^𝐱𝒩𝒞𝒳𝑇𝐲\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T),\mathbf{y}), i.e. for only those 𝐱^∈𝒞^𝐱𝒞\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{C} for which the line 𝐲​ℝ𝐲ℝ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{R} passes through its Euclidean nearest neighbor region. Furthermore, Theorem 1 implies that only a finite segment of the line need be considered. We have demonstrated such a search in Figure 1, which shows the positive axes for 8-ary PAM with T=2𝑇2T=2, where the shaded regions indicate the nearest neighbor regions of the points which need to be searched. The specifics of the algorithm are as follows.

First, for ease of notation we modify the received codeword 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} by changing the signs of all negative elements in 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}. This will mean that the corresponding (modified) 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} will now have all positive elements. The true (original) GLRT estimate of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} can be obtained by applying the reverse sign changes to 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}. Observe that we can do this without loss of generality since the PAM constellation is symmetric around zero.

Definition 3

We define P​(𝐱^)𝑃^𝐱P(\hat{\mathbf{x}}) to be the range of λ𝜆\lambda such that 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} is the nearest neighbor to λ​𝐲𝜆𝐲\lambda\mathbf{y}, within the limits 0<λ<λmax≜(M+T−2)/maxt⁡{yt}0𝜆superscript𝜆max≜𝑀𝑇2subscript𝑡subscript𝑦𝑡0<\lambda<\lambda^{\text{max}}\triangleq(M+T-2)/\max_{t}{\left\{y_{t}\right\}} (where the limits are due to Theorem 1 and the fact that all xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} are greater than zero for the modified received codeword). Formally,

P​(𝐱^)𝑃^𝐱\displaystyle P(\hat{\mathbf{x}}) ≜{λ|𝐱^∈N​N​(λ​𝐲),λ∈(0,λmax)}.≜absentconditional-set𝜆formulae-sequence^𝐱𝑁𝑁𝜆𝐲𝜆0superscript𝜆max\displaystyle\triangleq{\left\{\lambda\;|\;\hat{\mathbf{x}}\in NN(\lambda\mathbf{y}),\;\lambda\in(0,\lambda^{\text{max}})\right\}}.

Note that each non-empty P​(𝐱^)𝑃^𝐱P(\hat{\mathbf{x}}) corresponds to a distinct interval of the line 𝐲​ℝ𝐲ℝ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{R}. The proposed algorithm proceeds by enumerating these non-empty P​(𝐱^)𝑃^𝐱P(\hat{\mathbf{x}})’s, by first enumerating their boundary points along the line 𝐲​ℝ𝐲ℝ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{R}. We then sort the boundary points so that the decision metrics for the corresponding 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} can be calculated in an iterative manner.

For real-PAM, the boundary values of λ𝜆\lambda can be shown to be given by νt,b=bytsubscript𝜈𝑡𝑏𝑏subscript𝑦𝑡\nu_{t,b}=\frac{b}{y_{t}} for all t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\ldots,T and b=2,4,…,M−2𝑏24…𝑀2b=2,4,\ldots,M-2 such that 0<νt,b<λmax0subscript𝜈𝑡𝑏superscript𝜆max0<\nu_{t,b}<\lambda^{\text{max}} (where the values of b𝑏b come from the regular boundaries in the positive half of the PAM constellation 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}). We use 𝒱0subscript𝒱0\mathcal{V}_{0} to denote the set of all (νt,b,t)subscript𝜈𝑡𝑏𝑡(\nu_{t,b},t) pairs.

We then sort the elements of 𝒱0subscript𝒱0\mathcal{V}_{0} in ascending order of their νt,bsubscript𝜈𝑡𝑏\nu_{t,b} value, and append the value (λmax,0)superscript𝜆max0(\lambda^{\text{max}},0) to the end of the ordered set (since this is the outer boundary of the segment of the line 𝐲​ℝ𝐲ℝ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{R} which needs to be searched, according to Theorem 1; where the second element of the pair is arbitrarily set to 0 since it is not needed in the algorithm). We denote the newly ordered set by 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}, and index it by k𝑘k, (i.e. we denote its k𝑘kth element by (νk,tk)subscript𝜈𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘(\nu_{k}\,,\,t_{k})). These ordered values are shown on the example case of Figure 1, where the values of νksubscript𝜈𝑘\nu_{k} denote the distance along the line 𝐲​ℝ𝐲ℝ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{R} where the line crosses from one nearest neighbor region into the next.

We now show how 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} can be used to enumerate the codewords which need to be searched, and show how to calculate the corresponding decision metrics in an iterative manner. The algorithm can be visualized geometrically as searching along a segment of the line 𝐲​ℝ𝐲ℝ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{R}, by iterating in k𝑘k. Whenever the line crosses from the nearest neighbor region of one lattice point (codeword) to the nearest neighbor region of another, we calculate the metric for the new lattice point. Note that in this context, the value of tksubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k} indicates the dimension of the boundary that is going to be crossed (in the T𝑇T-dimensional space) when leaving the k𝑘kth segment of the line.

The iterative search starts with the codeword 𝐱^(1)=𝟏≜[ 1,1,…,1]′superscript^𝐱11≜superscript11…1′\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(1)}=\boldsymbol{1}\triangleq[\;1,1,\ldots,1]^{\prime}; which has a corresponding decision metric L​(𝟏)=(𝟏′​𝐲)2/‖𝟏‖2𝐿1superscriptsuperscript1′𝐲2superscriptnorm12L(\boldsymbol{1})=(\boldsymbol{1}^{\prime}\mathbf{y})^{2}/\left\|\boldsymbol{1}\right\|^{2}, where L​(𝐱^)≜(𝐱^′​𝐲)2/‖𝐱^‖2≜𝐿^𝐱superscriptsuperscript^𝐱′𝐲2superscriptnorm^𝐱2L(\hat{\mathbf{x}})\triangleq(\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\prime}\mathbf{y})^{2}/\left\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\|^{2} is the likelihood function in (4). We will use the symbol λ^^𝜆\hat{\lambda} as a marker for the most likely codeword, and we initially set it to λ^=ν1/2^𝜆subscript𝜈12\hat{\lambda}=\nu_{1}/2 (i.e. during the iteration process, λ^^𝜆\hat{\lambda} will be updated whenever a codeword is found to have a higher likelihood than any previously searched codeword, and the value of λ^^𝜆\hat{\lambda} will be chosen such that N​N​(λ^)𝑁𝑁^𝜆NN(\hat{\lambda}) gives the new codeword).

The iteration proceeds by noting that each time a nearest neighbor boundary is crossed, only one element of the T𝑇T-dimensional nearest neighbor codeword vector changes (since for real-PAM, the boundaries are straight lines, orthogonal to one of the dimensions, and parallel to all the others). Therefore the k𝑘kth codeword which needs to be considered, is calculated from the (k−1)𝑘1(k-1)th codeword, on an element-wise basis as follows:

x^p(k)={x^p(k−1),for​p≠tk−1x^p(k)+1,for​p=tk−1.subscriptsuperscript^𝑥𝑘𝑝casessubscriptsuperscript^𝑥𝑘1𝑝for𝑝subscript𝑡𝑘1subscriptsuperscript^𝑥𝑘𝑝1for𝑝subscript𝑡𝑘1\hat{x}^{(k)}_{p}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\hat{x}^{(k-1)}_{p},&\text{for}\;p\neq t_{k-1}\\ \hat{x}^{(k)}_{p}+1,&\text{for}\;p=t_{k-1}.\end{array}\right. (13)

We define αk≜(𝐱^(k))′​𝐲≜subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsuperscript^𝐱𝑘′𝐲\alpha_{k}\triangleq(\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)})^{\prime}\mathbf{y} and βk≜‖𝐱^(k)‖2≜subscript𝛽𝑘superscriptnormsuperscript^𝐱𝑘2\beta_{k}\triangleq\left\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)}\right\|^{2}, and hence L​(𝐱^(k))=αk2/βk𝐿superscript^𝐱𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘2subscript𝛽𝑘L(\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)})=\alpha_{k}^{2}/\beta_{k} is the decision metric for the k𝑘kth codeword considered. The values αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} and βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} are calculated iteratively as follows,

αksubscript𝛼𝑘\displaystyle\alpha_{k} =αk−1+2​ytk−1absentsubscript𝛼𝑘12subscript𝑦subscript𝑡𝑘1\displaystyle=\alpha_{k-1}+2y_{t_{k-1}} (14)
βksubscript𝛽𝑘\displaystyle\beta_{k} =βk−1+4​x^tk−1+4.absentsubscript𝛽𝑘14subscript^𝑥subscript𝑡𝑘14\displaystyle=\beta_{k-1}+4\hat{x}_{t_{k-1}}+4. (15)

If L​(𝐱^(k))𝐿superscript^𝐱𝑘L(\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)}) improves on the previous best codeword estimate then we update λ^^𝜆\hat{\lambda} in the interior of P​(𝐱^(k))𝑃superscript^𝐱𝑘P(\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)}), by setting λ^=(νk+νk−1)/2^𝜆subscript𝜈𝑘subscript𝜈𝑘12\hat{\lambda}=(\nu_{k}+\nu_{k-1})/2.

Once all segments of the line have been searched, we have 𝐱^opt=N​N​(λ^​𝐲)superscript^𝐱opt𝑁𝑁^𝜆𝐲\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}}=NN(\hat{\lambda}\mathbf{y}). Pseudo-code for the algorithm is given in Table III.

The complexity of the algorithm is a function of the number of intersection points νt,bsubscript𝜈𝑡𝑏\nu_{t,b}, i.e., NI≜|𝒱0|≜subscript𝑁𝐼subscript𝒱0N_{I}\triangleq{\left|\mathcal{V}_{0}\right|}, where |⋅|{\left|\cdot\right|} denotes set cardinality. NIsubscript𝑁𝐼N_{I} is upper bounded by (M/2−1)​T𝑀21𝑇(M/2-1)T, however in general it will be much less than this due to the restricted line search implied by Theorem 1, as shown by simulation in Section VII. The sorting of 𝒱0subscript𝒱0\mathcal{V}_{0} can be performed using standard sorting techniques in O​(NI​log⁡NI)𝑂subscript𝑁𝐼subscript𝑁𝐼O(N_{I}\log N_{I}) [26]. The updates (13), (14) and (15) have complexity O​(1)𝑂1O(1), and the final calculation of 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} is of order T𝑇T. Thus the overall complexity is dominated by the sorting operation, and hence the complexity of the algorithm is of order O​(T​log⁡T)𝑂𝑇𝑇O(T\log T); a significant improvement compared with an exhaustive search over all MTsuperscript𝑀𝑇M^{T} possible codewords in the codebook 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T).

V GLRT-Optimal QAM Detection For Complex-Valued Fading Channels

This section presents a low complexity algorithm for GLRT-optimal noncoherent QAM detection over complex-valued fading channels. Similarly to the the real-PAM case, we first present a theorem that we will use to reduce the number of codewords that need to be examined, beyond the limitations imposed by Property 1. In the complex-valued channel case, the subspace of interest is the plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2}, where 𝐘¯¯𝐘\mathbf{\underline{Y}} was defined in (8). The theorem implies that only a limited extent of the plane needs to be searched; and that the extent depends on the largest element in 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}. We then propose a fast low-complexity algorithm to perform the search for QAM. We also show how PAM detection over complex-valued channels can be viewed as a special case of the QAM algorithm.

V-A Limiting the Search Space

Theorem 2

For noncoherent detection of M2superscript𝑀2M^{2}-ary QAM codewords of length T𝑇T over a complex-valued fading channel

|Re⁡{λ^opt​yt}|Resuperscript^𝜆optsubscript𝑦𝑡\displaystyle{\left|\operatorname{Re}{\left\{\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}y_{t}\right\}}\right|} ⩽M+2​T−2,andabsent𝑀2𝑇2and\displaystyle\leqslant M+2T-2,\;\;\;\text{and}
|Im⁡{λ^opt​yt}|Imsuperscript^𝜆optsubscript𝑦𝑡\displaystyle{\left|\operatorname{Im}{\left\{\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}y_{t}\right\}}\right|} ⩽M+2​T−2,absent𝑀2𝑇2\displaystyle\leqslant M+2T-2,

for all t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,\ldots,T.

Proof:

Define the point 𝐯≜λ^opt​𝐲≜𝐯superscript^𝜆opt𝐲\mathbf{v}\triangleq\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}\mathbf{y}, along with its corresponding real-valued representation 𝐯¯¯𝐯\mathbf{\underline{v}}, as in (7). Also define n≜arg⁡maxt⁡{|vt|}≜𝑛subscript𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡n\triangleq\arg\max_{t}{\left\{{\left|v_{t}\right|}\right\}}. and therefore

for all t=1,…,2​T𝑡1…2𝑇t=1,\ldots,2T where we recall from Section II-A that 𝒳′={±1,±3,…,±(M−1)}superscript𝒳′plus-or-minus1plus-or-minus3…plus-or-minus𝑀1\mathcal{X}^{\prime}={\left\{\pm 1,\pm 3,\ldots,\pm(M-1)\right\}}. We now substitute (18) into (17) which gives

This is similar to (12) in the proof of Theorem 1. V-B QAM Algorithm

In this Section we use Property 1 and Theorem 2 to develop a low-complexity algorithm for QAM detection. Property 1 implies that 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} can be found by calculating the metric in (4) for only those 𝐱¯^∈𝒩​(𝒞​(𝒳,T),𝐘¯)^¯𝐱𝒩𝒞𝒳𝑇¯𝐘\hat{\mathbf{\underline{x}}}\in\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T),\mathbf{\underline{Y}}), i.e. for only those 𝐱¯^∈𝒞^¯𝐱𝒞\hat{\mathbf{\underline{x}}}\in\mathcal{C} for which the plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2} passes through its Euclidean nearest neighbor region. Furthermore, Theorem 2 implies that only a finite region of the plane need be considered. Conceptually, this is a direct extension of the real-PAM case shown in Figure 1 (considered previously). The difference being that Figure 1 shows the line 𝐲​ℝ𝐲ℝ\mathbf{y}\mathbb{R}, but we now have a plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2}. Also the number of orthogonal dimensions doubles when considering complex-valued channels. We demonstrated this complex-valued channel QAM case in Figure 2 which is a two dimensional plot in the plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2}. The parallel lines (at various angles) are the boundaries arising from the QAM constellation, and the shaded region indicates the nearest neighbor regions of codewords which need to be searched. The QAM search algorithm we present here, follows the same principles as the real-PAM algorithm of Section IV-B, where instead of working with boundary points of line segments, we need to work with boundary edges of planar regions. The specifics of the algorithm are as follows.

First, for ease of notation we modify the received codeword 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} by multiplying it by the complex scalar ym∗/|ym|superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑚subscript𝑦𝑚y_{m}^{*}/{\left|y_{m}\right|}, where m=arg⁡maxt⁡|yt|𝑚subscript𝑡subscript𝑦𝑡m=\arg\max_{t}{\left|y_{t}\right|}. This will mean that the m𝑚mth element of 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} will be real-valued and positive. The true (original) GLRT-optimal estimate of the channel can be be obtained by applying the reverse phase rotation to h^optsuperscript^ℎopt\smash{\hat{h}}^{\text{opt}}, while the optimality of the new GLRT-optimal codeword estimate is unaffected.

Hence Theorem 2 implies that the search over the plane 𝐘¯​𝝀¯𝐘𝝀\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\boldsymbol{\lambda} is reduced to the segment of the plane for which |λ1|,|λ2|<λmaxsubscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2superscript𝜆max{\left|\lambda_{1}\right|},{\left|\lambda_{2}\right|}<\lambda^{\text{max}} where λmax≜(M+2​T−2)/|ym|≜superscript𝜆max𝑀2𝑇2subscript𝑦𝑚\lambda^{\text{max}}\triangleq(M+2T-2)/{\left|y_{m}\right|}. Furthermore, as discussed in Section II-B because of the π/2𝜋2\pi/2 phase ambiguity in square QAM constellations, there are four GLRT-optimal inverse channel estimates ±λ^opt,±i​λ^optplus-or-minussuperscript^𝜆optplus-or-minus𝑖superscript^𝜆opt\pm\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}},\pm i\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}} (with corresponding phase ambiguous GLRT-optimal codeword estimates). Hence, we only need to consider the square region of the plane

𝒮={𝝀|λ1∈(0,λmax),λ2∈[0,λmax)}𝒮conditional-set𝝀formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆10superscript𝜆maxsubscript𝜆20superscript𝜆max\mathcal{S}={\left\{\;\boldsymbol{\lambda}\;|\;\lambda_{1}\in(0,\lambda^{\text{max}}),\;\lambda_{2}\in[0,\lambda^{\text{max}})\;\right\}} (20)

since exactly one of ±λ^opt,±i​λ^optplus-or-minussuperscript^𝜆optplus-or-minus𝑖superscript^𝜆opt\pm\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}},\pm i\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}} will exist in this region of the plane. Note that 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} is the shaded region in Figure 2 (mentioned previously).

Similarly to the real-PAM case we make the following definition.

Definition 4

We define P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) to be the range of 𝛌∈𝒮𝛌𝒮\boldsymbol{\lambda}\in\mathcal{S} such that 𝐱¯^¯^𝐱\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}} is the nearest neighbor to 𝐘¯​𝛌¯𝐘𝛌\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\boldsymbol{\lambda}. Formally,

P​(𝐱¯^)≜{𝝀|𝐱¯^∈N​N​(𝐘¯​𝝀),𝝀∈𝒮}.≜𝑃¯^𝐱conditional-set𝝀formulae-sequence¯^𝐱𝑁𝑁¯𝐘𝝀𝝀𝒮\displaystyle P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}})\triangleq{\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda}\;|\;\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\in NN(\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\boldsymbol{\lambda}),\;\boldsymbol{\lambda}\in\mathcal{S}\;\right\}}.

Note that each non-empty P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) corresponds to a distinct region of the plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2}. The proposed algorithm proceeds by enumerating these non-empty P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}})’s, by first enumerating their boundary vertices in the plane. These vertices are found by calculating the intersection of all the constellation-point boundary lines in the plane (e.g. as shown in Figure 2). The vertices are then used to calculate an interior-point inside each of the nearest neighbor regions in the shaded square 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. The respective nearest neighbor codeword is calculated for each interior-point, and then it is only these points for which the likelihood metrics are calculated. Clearly, this is a significantly reduced search space compared with the space of all possible codewords.

For QAM the vertices of the nearest-neighbor regions in the plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2} can be found by first noting that, since x¯^toptsubscriptsuperscript¯^𝑥opt𝑡\underline{\hat{x}}^{\text{opt}}_{t} can be given in on an element-wise basis as in (18), P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) can be written as

P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱\displaystyle P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) ≜⋂t=12​T{𝝀|x¯t=arg⁡minx¯∈𝒳′⁡|(𝐘¯​𝝀)t−x¯|,𝝀∈𝒮}≜absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑡12𝑇conditional-set𝝀formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝑥𝑡subscript¯𝑥superscript𝒳′subscript¯𝐘𝝀𝑡¯𝑥𝝀𝒮\displaystyle\triangleq\bigcap_{t=1}^{2T}\{\;\boldsymbol{\lambda}\;|\;\underline{x}_{t}=\arg\min_{\underline{x}\in{\mathcal{X}^{\prime}}}{\left|(\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\boldsymbol{\lambda})_{t}-\underline{x}\right|},\;\boldsymbol{\lambda}\in\mathcal{S}\}

where (𝐘¯​𝝀)tsubscript¯𝐘𝝀𝑡(\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\boldsymbol{\lambda})_{t} is the t𝑡tth element of 𝐘¯​𝝀¯𝐘𝝀\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\boldsymbol{\lambda} and we recall that 𝒳′={±1,±3,…,±(M−1)}superscript𝒳′plus-or-minus1plus-or-minus3…plus-or-minus𝑀1\mathcal{X}^{\prime}={\left\{\pm 1,\pm 3,\ldots,\pm(M-1)\right\}}. This can be written as the feasible region for the set of linear inequalities corresponding to the nearest neighbor region boundaries in 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}^{\prime} for each element of x¯^tsubscript¯^𝑥𝑡\underline{\hat{x}}_{t}, as

P​(𝐱¯^)=⋂t=12​T{𝝀|l​(x¯^t)⩽(𝐘¯​𝝀)t⩽u​(x¯^t),𝝀∈𝒮}𝑃¯^𝐱superscriptsubscript𝑡12𝑇conditional-set𝝀formulae-sequence𝑙subscript¯^𝑥𝑡subscript¯𝐘𝝀𝑡𝑢subscript¯^𝑥𝑡𝝀𝒮\displaystyle P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}})=\bigcap_{t=1}^{2T}{\left\{\;\boldsymbol{\lambda}\;|\;l(\underline{\hat{x}}_{t})\leqslant(\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\boldsymbol{\lambda})_{t}\leqslant u(\underline{\hat{x}}_{t}),\;\boldsymbol{\lambda}\in\mathcal{S}\right\}}

where l​(x¯^t)𝑙subscript¯^𝑥𝑡l(\underline{\hat{x}}_{t}) and u​(x¯^t)𝑢subscript¯^𝑥𝑡u(\underline{\hat{x}}_{t}) are the upper and lower nearest neighbor boundaries in the constellation 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}^{\prime}. For t∉{2​m,2​m−1}𝑡2𝑚2𝑚1t\notin{\left\{2m,2m-1\right\}} they take on values in the set {0,±2,…,±(M−2),±∞}0plus-or-minus2…plus-or-minus𝑀2plus-or-minus{\left\{0,\pm 2,\ldots,\pm(M-2),\pm\infty\right\}}. For t∈{2​m,2​m−1}𝑡2𝑚2𝑚1t\in{\left\{2m,2m-1\right\}} we must consider intersections with the boundary of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, and therefore in this case l​(x¯^t)𝑙subscript¯^𝑥𝑡l(\underline{\hat{x}}_{t}) and u​(x¯^t)𝑢subscript¯^𝑥𝑡u(\underline{\hat{x}}_{t}) take on values in the set {0,±2,…,±(M−2),±(M+2​T−2)}0plus-or-minus2…plus-or-minus𝑀2plus-or-minus𝑀2𝑇2{\left\{0,\pm 2,\ldots,\pm(M-2),\pm(M+2T-2)\right\}}.

By including the square boundary of the region 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, all non-empty P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) are closed simply connected sets on the plane ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}. Therefore, since P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) is formed from linear inequalities it is a convex polygon in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}. For each P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}), denote B​(𝐱¯^)𝐵¯^𝐱B(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) as its polygonal boundary and V​(𝐱¯^)𝑉¯^𝐱V(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) as the vertices of the polygon.

We now propose a method that enumerates all the vertices V​(𝐱¯^)𝑉¯^𝐱V(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) for all non-empty P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}), and then uses these vertices to generate a point in the interior of all P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}), which is then used to obtain a unique codeword via finding the nearest neighbor codeword to that point. Consider the set of points {𝝂±ϵ​𝝁|𝝂∈V​(𝐱¯^)}conditional-setplus-or-minus𝝂italic-ϵ𝝁𝝂𝑉¯^𝐱{\left\{\;\boldsymbol{\nu}\pm\epsilon\boldsymbol{\mu}\;|\boldsymbol{\nu}\in V(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}})\right\}}. If 𝝁𝝁\boldsymbol{\mu} is some vector that is not parallel to any side of the polygon P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}), and if ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is chosen sufficiently small, then at least one point in this set will be in the interior of P​(𝐱¯)𝑃¯𝐱P(\mathbf{\underline{x}}). Since the received symbol is subject to AWGN, and is therefore irrational with probability one, it follows that the arbitrary choice of 𝝁≜[ 1 1]′≜𝝁superscriptdelimited-[]11′\boldsymbol{\mu}\triangleq[\;1\;1\;]^{\prime} will almost surely guarantee this, given that ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 is chosen sufficiently small. In practice, simply setting ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon to some small positive constant will be sufficient to ensure that a point in the interior of P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) is enumerated. However, in Appendix -A we present a technique to perform this in a strictly optimal fashion with complexity per vertex of O​(T)𝑂𝑇O(T).

Since the vertices are shared by adjacent P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}), each vertex is only required to be enumerated once. We define the set of all vertices within or on the boundary of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} as 𝒱={𝝂|𝝂∈V​(𝐱¯^),P​(𝐱¯^)≠∅}𝒱conditional-set𝝂formulae-sequence𝝂𝑉¯^𝐱𝑃¯^𝐱\mathcal{V}={\left\{\;\boldsymbol{\nu}\;|\;\boldsymbol{\nu}\in V(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}),\;P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}})\neq\emptyset\;\right\}}. The set 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} can be enumerated as the the intersections of the lines Y¯t,1​ν1+Y¯t,2​ν2=bsubscript¯𝑌𝑡1subscript𝜈1subscript¯𝑌𝑡2subscript𝜈2𝑏\underline{Y}_{t,1}\nu_{1}+\underline{Y}_{t,2}\nu_{2}=b and Y¯t′,1​ν1+Y¯t′,2​ν2=b′subscript¯𝑌superscript𝑡′1subscript𝜈1subscript¯𝑌superscript𝑡′2subscript𝜈2superscript𝑏′\underline{Y}_{t^{\prime},1}\nu_{1}+\underline{Y}_{t^{\prime},2}\nu_{2}=b^{\prime}, for all pairs of t,t′𝑡superscript𝑡′t,t^{\prime} and for all nearest neighbor boundaries b,b′𝑏superscript𝑏′b,b^{\prime} in 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}^{\prime}. That is

[ν1ν2]=[Y¯t,1Y¯t,1Y¯t,2Y¯t,2]−1​[bb′]delimited-[]matrixsubscript𝜈1subscript𝜈2superscriptdelimited-[]matrixsubscript¯𝑌𝑡1subscript¯𝑌𝑡1subscript¯𝑌𝑡2subscript¯𝑌𝑡21delimited-[]matrix𝑏superscript𝑏′{\left[\begin{matrix}\nu_{1}\\ \nu_{2}\end{matrix}\right]}={\left[\begin{matrix}\underline{Y}_{t,1}&\underline{Y}_{t,1}\\ \underline{Y}_{t,2}&\underline{Y}_{t,2}\end{matrix}\right]}^{-1}{\left[\begin{matrix}b\\ b^{\prime}\end{matrix}\right]} (21)

for all t=1,2,…,2​T−1𝑡12…2𝑇1t=1,2,\ldots,2T-1, t′=t+1,t+2,…,2​Tsuperscript𝑡′𝑡1𝑡2…2𝑇t^{\prime}=t+1,t+2,\ldots,2T, and b,b′∈ℬ​(t)𝑏superscript𝑏′ℬ𝑡b,b^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}(t), where ℬ​(t)≜{0,±2,…,±(M−2)}≜ℬ𝑡0plus-or-minus2…plus-or-minus𝑀2\mathcal{B}(t)\triangleq{\left\{0,\pm 2,\ldots,\pm(M-2)\right\}} if t∉{2​m,2​m−1}𝑡2𝑚2𝑚1t\notin{\left\{2m,2m-1\right\}} and for symbol indices t∈{2​m,2​m−1}𝑡2𝑚2𝑚1t\in{\left\{2m,2m-1\right\}} where we consider the square boundary ℬ​(t)≜{0,±2,…,±(M−2),±(M+2​T−2)}≜ℬ𝑡0plus-or-minus2…plus-or-minus𝑀2plus-or-minus𝑀2𝑇2\mathcal{B}(t)\triangleq{\left\{0,\pm 2,\ldots,\pm(M-2),\pm(M+2T-2)\right\}}.

To enumerate a point in each P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}), for each vertex 𝝂𝝂\boldsymbol{\nu} enumerated we calculate the points on the plane 𝝀+≜𝝂+ϵ​𝝁≜superscript𝝀𝝂italic-ϵ𝝁\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{+}\triangleq\boldsymbol{\nu}+\epsilon\boldsymbol{\mu}, and 𝝀−≜𝝂+ϵ​𝝁≜superscript𝝀𝝂italic-ϵ𝝁\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{-}\triangleq\boldsymbol{\nu}+\epsilon\boldsymbol{\mu}. Then for each of these two points, if it is in the square 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, we calculate the corresponding codewords N​N​(𝝀+​𝐘¯)𝑁𝑁superscript𝝀¯𝐘NN(\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{+}\mathbf{\underline{Y}}) and/or N​N​(𝝀−​𝐘¯)𝑁𝑁superscript𝝀¯𝐘NN(\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{-}\mathbf{\underline{Y}}) and the decision metrics in (4).

The complexity of the algorithm is a function of the number of codewords examined, NCsubscript𝑁𝐶N_{C}, which is in turn a function of the number of vertices calculated. The number of vertices calculated in (21) corresponding to the intersections between lines in where b,b′𝑏superscript𝑏′b,b^{\prime} is a boundary of 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}^{\prime} and both b𝑏b and b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime} are non-zero is T​(2​T−1)​[(M−1)2−1]𝑇2𝑇1delimited-[]superscript𝑀121T(2T-1)[(M-1)^{2}-1]; for which at most two codewords are generated for a quarter of these intersections. For the intersections of the boundaries of 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}^{\prime} and the square 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} there are 2​(2​T−2)​(M−1)222𝑇2superscript𝑀122(2T-2)(M-1)^{2} intersections, which for one quarter of these intersections one codeword is generated. For the vertices at (0,0)00(0,0) and (λmax,λmax)superscript𝜆maxsuperscript𝜆max(\lambda^{\text{max}},\lambda^{\text{max}}) one codeword is generated. Hence the total number of codewords examined is at most

NC⩽T​(2​T−1)2​[(M−1)2−1]+(2​T−2)​(M−1)2+2.subscript𝑁𝐶𝑇2𝑇12delimited-[]superscript𝑀1212𝑇2superscript𝑀122N_{C}\leqslant\frac{T(2T-1)}{2}[(M-1)^{2}-1]+(2T-2)(M-1)^{2}+2. (22)

Since the complexity of each codeword and decision metric calculation is of order T𝑇T then the overall complexity is of order M2​T3superscript𝑀2superscript𝑇3M^{2}T^{3} (which is linear in the constellation size M2superscript𝑀2M^{2}) a significant improvement over an exhaustive search over all M2​Tsuperscript𝑀2𝑇M^{2T} possible codewords in the codebook 𝒞​(𝒳,T)𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X},T).

A further reduction in computational expense, without any loss in optimality, can be achieved by enumerating only one out of each set of four phase ambiguous vertices. The technique is not presented here due to space constraints, however the number of non-zero vertices examined is reduced by a factor of 4 and 1/3131/3 of the matrix inverse calculations in (21) are avoided.

V-C PAM Over Complex Channels

PAM detection over complex fading channels can be viewed as a special case of complex-channel QAM, where there is zero imaginary component in the constellation. In this case, the search over the plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2} can be restricted by extending the proof of Theorem 2. To do this, we note that the condition in (16) holds, which implies that (𝐱^opt)′​(Re⁡{λ^opt​𝐲}−𝐱^opt)=0superscriptsuperscript^𝐱opt′Resuperscript^𝜆opt𝐲superscript^𝐱opt0(\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}})^{\prime}(\operatorname{Re}{\left\{\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}\mathbf{y}\right\}}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}})=0 since 𝐱^optsuperscript^𝐱opt\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{\text{opt}} is always real-valued. The rest of the proof follows to give the result that |Re⁡{λ^opt​yt}|⩽M+T−2Resuperscript^𝜆optsubscript𝑦𝑡𝑀𝑇2{\left|\operatorname{Re}{\left\{\smash{\hat{\lambda}}^{\text{opt}}y_{t}\right\}}\right|}\leqslant M+T-2. This fact combined with Property 1 and the π𝜋\pi phase ambiguity of PAM constellations, implies that we only consider codewords 𝐱¯^=N​N​(𝐘¯​𝝀)¯^𝐱𝑁𝑁¯𝐘𝝀\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}=NN(\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\boldsymbol{\lambda}) for 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda} in the region 𝒮={𝝀| 0<λ1<λmax=(M+T−2)/|ym|}𝒮conditional-set𝝀 0subscript𝜆1superscript𝜆max𝑀𝑇2subscript𝑦𝑚\mathcal{S}={\left\{\;\boldsymbol{\lambda}\;|\;0<\lambda_{1}<\lambda^{\text{max}}=(M+T-2)/{\left|y_{m}\right|}\;\right\}}.

The specifics of the M𝑀M-ary PAM algorithm are the same as for the M2superscript𝑀2M^{2}-ary QAM case, with the exception that the calculation of (21) to obtain the vertices in the interior of the (21) is only performed for all t=1,3,…,2​T−1𝑡13…2𝑇1t=1,3,\ldots,2T-1, t′=t+2,t+4,…,2​Tsuperscript𝑡′𝑡2𝑡4…2𝑇t^{\prime}=t+2,t+4,\ldots,2T, and b,b′∈ℬ​(t)𝑏superscript𝑏′ℬ𝑡b,b^{\prime}\in\mathcal{B}(t), where ℬ​(t)≜{0,±2,…,±(M−2)}≜ℬ𝑡0plus-or-minus2…plus-or-minus𝑀2\mathcal{B}(t)\triangleq{\left\{0,\pm 2,\ldots,\pm(M-2)\right\}} if t≠2​m−1𝑡2𝑚1t\neq 2m-1 and for ℬ​(t)≜{0,±2,…,±(M−2),M+T−2}≜ℬ𝑡0plus-or-minus2…plus-or-minus𝑀2𝑀𝑇2\mathcal{B}(t)\triangleq{\left\{0,\pm 2,\ldots,\pm(M-2),M+T-2\right\}} if t=2​m−1𝑡2𝑚1t=2m-1.

The total number of codewords searched can be shown to be at most

NC⩽T​(T−1)2​[(M−1)2−1]+(T−1)​(M−1)+1.subscript𝑁𝐶𝑇𝑇12delimited-[]superscript𝑀121𝑇1𝑀11N_{C}\leqslant\frac{T(T-1)}{2}[(M-1)^{2}-1]+(T-1)(M-1)+1. (23)

Since the complexity of each codeword and decision metric calculation is of order T𝑇T then the overall complexity is O​(T3)𝑂superscript𝑇3O(T^{3}). In the following section, we will see that a simple suboptimal approach can achieve even lower complexity with near-optimal performance.

VI Suboptimal Algorithms for Complex-Valued Fading Channels

In this section, we propose even lower complexity suboptimal algorithms for detection of QAM and PAM over complex-valued fading channels. We directly use the GLRT-optimal algorithm for real-PAM from Section IV as the basis for the algorithms.

VI-A Suboptimal PAM algorithm

Since for PAM constellations, all constellation points lie along the real line in the complex plane, a suboptimal phase estimation technique combined with our GLRT-optimal algorithm for real-valued fading channels should be sufficient to provide near-optimal performance. This effectively reduces the search over the whole plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2} for the GLRT-optimal case, to a search over a single line at the given estimated phase angle.

We use the power-law estimator [27] which, for constellations exhibiting a rotational symmetry of π𝜋\pi radians, is simply

ϕ^PL≜12​∠​∑t=1Tyt2≜subscript^italic-ϕPL12∠superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑡2\hat{\phi}_{\text{PL}}\triangleq\frac{1}{2}\angle{\sum_{t=1}^{T}y_{t}^{2}} (24)

where ∠∠\angle refers to the complex argument. Detection is performed by first rotating the received codeword 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} according to this estimate, and then detecting Re⁡{e−j​ϕ^PL​𝐲}Resuperscript𝑒𝑗subscript^italic-ϕPL𝐲\operatorname{Re}\{e^{-j\hat{\phi}_{\text{PL}}}\mathbf{y}\} using the GLRT-optimal algorithm of PAM over a real-valued fading channel.

VI-B Suboptimal QAM algorithm

Here we propose a suboptimal algorithm, which reduces the overall algorithmic complexity to O​(T2​log⁡T)𝑂superscript𝑇2𝑇O(T^{2}\log T) by using O​(T)𝑂𝑇O(T) instances of the PAM detection algorithm presented in Section IV. Instead of enumerating the intersections of lines on the (λ1,λ2)subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2})-plane, as we did in Section V-B, here we propose to use a modified version of the nearest-neighbor real-PAM line-search algorithm for L𝐿L lines of the type presented in Section IV. We generate these lines emanating from the origin into 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} (the shaded region in Figure 2), evenly spaced in angle. Of course, this does not guarantee that we fully enumerate 𝒩​(𝒞​(𝒳),T)𝒩𝒞𝒳𝑇\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{C}(\mathcal{X}),T) since a finite number of radiating lines can not completely cover a plane, however, we will see by simulation in Section V-B that the performance is close to the optimal.

As in the optimal case, we multiply 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} by ym∗/|ym|superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑚subscript𝑦𝑚y_{m}^{*}/{\left|y_{m}\right|} so that ymsubscript𝑦𝑚y_{m} will be real-valued and positive. The L𝐿L directions of the lines with respect to the direction of positive λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1} have angles Φ≜{ϕ1,…,ϕL}≜Φsubscriptitalic-ϕ1…subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐿\Phi\triangleq{\left\{\phi_{1},\ldots,\phi_{L}\right\}} where ϕℓ=(ℓ−1)​π/(2​L)subscriptitalic-ϕℓℓ1𝜋2𝐿\phi_{\ell}=({\ell}-1)\pi/(2L). The significantly reduced algorithmic complexity compared to the GLRT-optimal algorithm is governed by the number of line searches and the complexity of each line search. Note that however, the improved computational performance of the algorithm is largely due to being able to choose L𝐿L small, which corresponds to avoiding examining a significant number of the 𝐱¯^¯^𝐱\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}} with associated P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) being so small as to imply that 𝐱¯^¯^𝐱\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}} is not relatively close in angle to the plane 𝐘¯​ℝ2¯𝐘superscriptℝ2\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\mathbb{R}^{2}. We will see via simulation in Section VII that small L𝐿L (e.g. L=4𝐿4L=4 for T=7𝑇7T=7 16-QAM detection) can achieve near-optimal performance.

VII Simulation Results

We now present simulation results to demonstrate the performance of the new PAM and QAM noncoherent reduced search lattice-decoding algorithms. Simulations are performed to obtain the codeword error rate (CER) as a function of SNR for noncoherent detection of 8-ary PAM and 16-ary square QAM. For both case, the simulations are performed for codeword lengths of T=3𝑇3T=3 and 777 over a block Rayleigh fading channel where hℎh is i.i.d. circularly symmetric complex Gaussian with unit variance. We have assumed that the phase ambiguities have been removed within each codeword, (for example, by the use of differential encoding [10]).

Figure 3 presents results for 8-ary PAM for the GLRT-optimal plane search algorithm from Section V-C and the suboptimal phase-estimator plus line-search algorithm from Section VI-A. We also compare with the suboptimal grid-search algorithm proposed in [20] and the quantization based receiver proposed in [11]. For the grid-search algorithm we use uniformly spaced channel phase estimates and the channel attenuation estimates are chosen uniformly from the CDF of the Rayleigh fading channel distribution. For fairness the number of channel attenuation estimates is adjusted so that the total number of channel estimates was kept equal to the maximum number of codeword estimates that potentially could be produced by our GLRT-optimal algorithm. Best results are obtained for choosing the channel phase estimates as 00 and π/2𝜋2\pi/2, and hence the k𝑘kth channel amplitude estimate is given by |h^(k)|2=−log⁡(1−k/(1+⌈NC/L⌉))superscriptsuperscript^ℎ𝑘21𝑘1subscript𝑁𝐶𝐿|\hat{h}^{(k)}|^{2}=-\log(1-k/(1+\lceil N_{C}/L\rceil)). For the quantization-based receiver (QBR) considered in [11], all possible sequences of (positive) amplitude levels are produced, and the sign of each symbol is then determined by symbol-wise coherent detection using uniformly spaced channel phase estimates (a channel amplitude estimate is not required since the signal amplitude is assumed known). For QBR, we again use the channel phase estimates 00 and π/2𝜋2\pi/2.

Figure 4 presents the CER as a function of SNR, for 16-QAM transmission. Results are shown for the GLRT-optimal QAM algorithm given in Section V-B and the suboptimal algorithm given in Section VI-B. We also compare with the grid-based algorithm, where best performance for a fixed number of codeword estimates was obtained using L=4𝐿4L=4 channel phase estimates, which we also use for QBR.

For both the PAM and QAM cases we see that the suboptimal line-search algorithms provide negligible performance loss compared to the GLRT-optimal algorithm. For the case of T=3𝑇3T=3, where QBR is computationally possible, there is a noticeable performance loss. As discussed in Section II-B, divisor ambiguities result in a lower bound on the CER. Expressions for these lower bounds were provided in [25] and are also shown in the figure. Clearly, for high SNR, both of our GLRT-optimal algorithms and both suboptimal algorithms detection achieve these bounds for both PAM and QAM. As noted in [11], there is an inherent suboptimality introduced by quantizing the unbounded channel attenuation by employing a grid-search approach, and hence the performance is clearly inferior. Also, although QBR achieves near-optimal performance for T=3𝑇3T=3, since the complexity of QBR increases exponentially with T𝑇T is not possible to produce curves for T=7𝑇7T=7.

In Table I we present the relative computational complexities of the algorithms for the simulations in terms of the average number of codewords examined. The numbers in brackets indicate the number of codewords examined by the search if the restrictions on the search region provided by Theorems 1 and 2 are not applied (and are therefore slightly greater than the worst case values given in (22) and (23)). We see that the suboptimal phase-estimator plus line-search approaches examine far fewer codewords yet obtains near-optimal performance, and that the complexity of QBR quickly becomes infeasible with increasing T𝑇T.

VIII Reduced Ambiguity Transmission

In this section we extend our new noncoherent detection algorithm to pilot assisted transmission (PAT) systems [6]. Unlike, standard PAT we propose to use the pilot symbol for noncoherent ambiguity resolution, rather than simply for channel estimation. We propose to replace the pilot symbol of PAT with a symbol generated in the following way. Two bits are allocated for resolving the π/2𝜋2\pi/2 phase ambiguity of square QAM, and the remaining bits in the symbol are allocated to parity, remove divisor ambiguities and improve error performance. Therefore, this scheme has the same data rate as PAT and can be compared directly.

With parity check bits in the codeword, we can now even further reduce the search space of our reduced search GLRT lattice-decoding algorithm by only considering codewords which satisfy a parity check. This significantly reduces the ambiguity problem. We will denote this parity-aided transmission scheme as reduced ambiguity (RA) transmission.

An arbitrarily chosen parity check scheme might reduce the number of divisor ambiguities, however since the metric (4) has a geometric interpretation it may be possible to design other parity-check schemes which both resolve ambiguities and optimize performance by providing a minimum angular separation between codewords. The resolution of ambiguities can be achieved, at least for 16-QAM, by using the following parity-check scheme. Two parity bits p1,p2subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2p_{1},p_{2} are calculated from the data bits {d1,d2,…,d2​(T−1)}subscript𝑑1subscript𝑑2…subscript𝑑2𝑇1\{d_{1},d_{2},\ldots,d_{2(T-1)}\} as follows,

p1subscript𝑝1\displaystyle p_{1} ≡1+∑t=14​(T−1)dtabsent1superscriptsubscript𝑡14𝑇1subscript𝑑𝑡\displaystyle\equiv 1+\sum_{t=1}^{4(T-1)}{d_{t}} (28)
p2subscript𝑝2\displaystyle p_{2} ≡1+∑t=12​(T−1)d2​tabsent1superscriptsubscript𝑡12𝑇1subscript𝑑2𝑡\displaystyle\equiv 1+\sum_{t=1}^{2(T-1)}{d_{2t}} (29)

where ≡\equiv denotes equality in G​F​(2)𝐺𝐹2GF(2). They are then mapped to the upper right-hand quadrant of the QAM constellation of the first (pilot) symbol in the codeword as follows: (00)↣1+j↣001𝑗(00)\rightarrowtail 1+j, (01)↣1+3​j↣0113𝑗(01)\rightarrowtail 1+3j, (11)↣3+3​j↣1133𝑗(11)\rightarrowtail 3+3j and (10)↣3+j↣103𝑗(10)\rightarrowtail 3+j. Effectively this means the first two bits of the first symbol of each codeword is chosen such that x¯1,x¯2>0subscript¯𝑥1subscript¯𝑥20\underline{x}_{1},\underline{x}_{2}>0, which removes the π/2𝜋2\pi/2 phase ambiguity, and the other two bits are parity bits, which in this case can be shown to completely remove the divisor ambiguities (see Appendix -B).

Figure 5 presents the bit error rate (BER) as a function of SNR for detection of 16-QAM transmitted over a block independent phase-noncoherent AWGN channel. Again we have assumed that the phase ambiguities have been removed within each codeword. Results are shown for three codeword lengths T=3,5,7𝑇357T=3,5,7. The figure shows curves for our new RA reduced-search GLRT-optimal algorithm, and compares them to standard PAT. Both schemes use a single pilot symbol per codeword; which for the RA scheme is generated as described above, and for PAT it is a symbol which has energy equal to the average energy per symbol. For PAT, the GLRT estimate of the channel (based on the pilot symbol) is used to perform GLRT-optimal data detection, while for RA lattice decoding we use our reduced search GLRT-optimal algorithm. Note that for PAT, the BER is independent of the codeword length T𝑇T since it is a symbol-by-symbol detection scheme, whereas for RA lattice decoding the BER decreases as T𝑇T increases since it is a sequence detection scheme. Clearly our scheme outperforms PAT increasingly with T𝑇T.

Figure 6 shows the CER for the scenario of Figure 5. This serves to highlight even further the benefit from our lattice (sequence) decoding approach compared with PAT. For PAT, since bit errors occur independently on a symbol-by-symbol basis, the CER increases with T𝑇T. However, for RA lattice decoding the CER decreases. Also the figure highlights the advantage of using pilot symbols, compared with fully noncoherent transmission, by observing that the SNR range is significantly lower than for Figures 3 and 4.

IX Conclusion

In this paper we developed polynomial-time lattice-decoding algorithms for noncoherent block detection of PAM and QAM. Faster suboptimal algorithms for QAM were also presented which have excellent agreement with the optimal algorithms. A reduced ambiguity transmission scheme was introduced which was shown to outperform pilot assisted transmission over the phase noncoherent channel.

-A Strictly Optimal Calculation of Interior Points

For each non-empty region P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}), there exists a vertex 𝝂∈V​(𝐱¯^)𝝂𝑉¯^𝐱\boldsymbol{\nu}\in V(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) and small scalars ν+,ν−>0superscript𝜈superscript𝜈0\nu^{+},\nu^{-}>0, such that either 𝝂+≜𝝂+[ν+​ 0]′≜superscript𝝂𝝂superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝜈 0′\boldsymbol{\nu}^{+}\triangleq\boldsymbol{\nu}+[\;\nu^{+}\;0\;]^{\prime} or 𝝂−≜𝝂+[ν−​ 0]′≜superscript𝝂𝝂superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝜈 0′\boldsymbol{\nu}^{-}\triangleq\boldsymbol{\nu}+[\;\nu^{-}\;0\;]^{\prime} is in the interior of P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}).

Suppose the first case is true. Now, the line 𝝂+γ​[ 1 0]′𝝂𝛾superscriptdelimited-[]10′\boldsymbol{\nu}+\gamma[\;1\;0\;]^{\prime}intersects an edge of the boundary of P​(𝐱¯)𝑃¯𝐱P(\mathbf{\underline{x}}), and we will call this intersection point 𝝁𝝁\boldsymbol{\mu}. We propose to choose ν+=γ>0superscript𝜈𝛾0\nu^{+}=\gamma>0 so that 𝝂+superscript𝝂\boldsymbol{\nu}^{+} is the midpoint of 𝝂𝝂\boldsymbol{\nu} and 𝝁𝝁\boldsymbol{\mu}. Defining u¯tsubscript¯𝑢𝑡\underline{u}_{t} as the t𝑡tth element of 𝐮¯=𝐘¯​𝝂¯𝐮¯𝐘𝝂\mathbf{\underline{u}}=\mathbf{\underline{Y}}\,\boldsymbol{\nu}, where 𝐘¯¯𝐘\mathbf{\underline{Y}} is defined by the original received vector 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}, we can calculate ν+superscript𝜈\nu^{+} as follows,

ν+={mint​2​⌈u¯t2⌉−u¯t2​y¯ty¯t<0,mint−2​⌊u¯t2⌋−u¯t2​y¯ty¯t>0.superscript𝜈cases𝑡2subscript¯𝑢𝑡2subscript¯𝑢𝑡2subscript¯𝑦𝑡subscript¯𝑦𝑡0𝑡2subscript¯𝑢𝑡2subscript¯𝑢𝑡2subscript¯𝑦𝑡subscript¯𝑦𝑡0\nu^{+}=\begin{cases}\begin{subarray}{c}\min\\ t\end{subarray}\frac{2\lceil\tfrac{\underline{u}_{t}}{2}\rceil-\underline{u}_{t}}{2\underline{y}_{t}}&\underline{y}_{t}<0,\\ \begin{subarray}{c}\min\\ t\end{subarray}-\frac{2\lfloor\tfrac{\underline{u}_{t}}{2}\rfloor-\underline{u}_{t}}{2\underline{y}_{t}}&\underline{y}_{t}>0.\end{cases}

Note that almost surely y¯t≠0subscript¯𝑦𝑡0\underline{y}_{t}\neq 0. Similarly, using the line 𝝂−γ​[ 1 0]′𝝂𝛾superscriptdelimited-[]10′\boldsymbol{\nu}-\gamma[\;1\;0\;]^{\prime} we calculate ν−=γ>0superscript𝜈𝛾0\nu^{-}=\gamma>0 as

This process will in general always calculate a point in each non-empty P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}). However, to avoid calculation problems we first rotate ν𝜈\nu by ym/|ym|subscript𝑦𝑚subscript𝑦𝑚y_{m}/{\left|y_{m}\right|}, so that the vectors [ν+​ 0]′superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝜈 0′[\;\nu^{+}\;0\;]^{\prime} and [ν−​ 0]′superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝜈 0′[\;\nu^{-}\;0\;]^{\prime} are not parallel to any of the edges of P​(𝐱¯^)𝑃¯^𝐱P(\underline{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}) (e.g. those that are part of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}). This rotation is later reversed, so that the points calculated are in the original coordinates.

-B Removal of Ambiguities in 16-ary QAM

In this section we show that the proposed RA pilot symbol approach (using parity checks, as discussed in Section VIII) totally removes both the phase and divisor ambiguities otherwise inherent in a noncoherent detection system (as discussed in Section II-A).
We start by recalling that the proposed parity scheme involves calculating the parity bits from the data bits dtsubscript𝑑𝑡d_{t} for t=1,…,4​T𝑡1…4𝑇t=1,\ldots,4T as follows.

p1≡1+∑ℓ=14​(T−1)dtp2≡1+∑ℓ=12​(T−1)d2​tformulae-sequencesubscript𝑝11superscriptsubscriptℓ14𝑇1subscript𝑑𝑡subscript𝑝21superscriptsubscriptℓ12𝑇1subscript𝑑2𝑡p_{1}\equiv 1+\sum_{\ell=1}^{4(T-1)}{d_{t}}\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;p_{2}\equiv 1+\sum_{\ell=1}^{2(T-1)}{d_{2t}} (30)

where ≡\equiv denotes equality in G​F​(2)𝐺𝐹2GF(2).

The data and parity bits are then mapped to the symbols as shown in Table II, where we recall from the definition in (7) that x¯2​t−1=Re⁡{xt}subscript¯𝑥2𝑡1Resubscript𝑥𝑡\underline{x}_{2t-1}=\operatorname{Re}{\left\{x_{t}\right\}} and x¯2​t=Im⁡{xt}subscript¯𝑥2𝑡Imsubscript𝑥𝑡\underline{x}_{2t}=\operatorname{Im}{\left\{x_{t}\right\}}.

Since x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} is constrained to have positive real and imaginary components, the phase ambiguity has been removed. It remains to show that all divisor ambiguities have also been removed.

To do this, we first define the associates of a Gaussian integer g𝑔g to be the elements of the set A​(g)={g,g​i,−g,−g​i}𝐴𝑔𝑔𝑔𝑖𝑔𝑔𝑖A(g)=\{g,gi,-g,-gi\}. We also denote A​(g)T𝐴superscript𝑔𝑇A(g)^{T} to be a codeword of length T𝑇T composed of only elements of A​(g)𝐴𝑔A(g). For 16-QAM, it can be easily shown that a necessary condition for a divisor ambiguity to exist is that there exists codewords 𝐱(1)∈A​(g1)Tsuperscript𝐱1𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝑇\mathbf{x}^{(1)}\in A(g_{1})^{T}, 𝐱(2)∈A​(g2)Tsuperscript𝐱2𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑔2𝑇\mathbf{x}^{(2)}\in A(g_{2})^{T} for some g1,g2∈𝒳≜{1+i,3+3​i,3+i,1+3​i}subscript𝑔1subscript𝑔2𝒳≜1𝑖33𝑖3𝑖13𝑖g_{1},g_{2}\in\mathcal{X}\triangleq\{1+i,3+3i,3+i,1+3i\} such that g1≠g2subscript𝑔1subscript𝑔2g_{1}\neq g_{2}.

For a codeword 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and some g∈𝒳𝑔𝒳g\in\mathcal{X}, we define N1,N2,N3subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁2subscript𝑁3N_{1},N_{2},N_{3} and N4subscript𝑁4N_{4} as the number of occurrences in a codeword of each of the four possible rotations of g𝑔g in the codeword, that is g,g​i,−g𝑔𝑔𝑖𝑔g,gi,-g and −g​i𝑔𝑖-gi respectively. Noting that the phase ambiguity has been removed (since x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} is constrained to have positive real and imaginary components), a sufficient condition for two codewords to be unambiguous is that there exists some t𝑡t, such that the t𝑡tth symbols from the two codewords are in different quadrants of the complex plane. It follows then, that a sufficient condition for two codewords to be unambiguous is that they do not have the same values of N1subscript𝑁1N_{1} to N4subscript𝑁4N_{4}.

We now use this property on N1subscript𝑁1N_{1} to N4subscript𝑁4N_{4} to show that for arbitrary T𝑇T, it is not possible for two ambiguous codewords 𝐱(1)∈A​(g1)Tsuperscript𝐱1𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝑇\mathbf{x}^{(1)}\in A(g_{1})^{T}, 𝐱(2)∈A​(g2)Tsuperscript𝐱2𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑔2𝑇\mathbf{x}^{(2)}\in A(g_{2})^{T}, to satisfy the parity check (30) for any g1,g2∈𝒳subscript𝑔1subscript𝑔2𝒳g_{1},g_{2}\in\mathcal{X} such that g1≠g2subscript𝑔1subscript𝑔2g_{1}\neq g_{2}.

If T𝑇T is odd then p1≡1+N2+N4subscript𝑝11subscript𝑁2subscript𝑁4p_{1}\equiv 1+N_{2}+N_{4} and p2≡1subscript𝑝21p_{2}\equiv 1. Therefore,

    x1={1+3​iif ​(p1​p2)=(01)​ i.e. if ​N2≢N4,3+3​i,if ​(p1​p2)=(11)​ i.e. if ​N2≡N4.x_{1}=\Bigg{\{}\begin{matrix}1+3i&\text{if }(p_{1}p_{2})=(01)\text{\emph{~{}~{}i.e.} if~{}~{}}N_{2}\not\equiv N_{4},\\ 3+3i,&\text{if }(p_{1}p_{2})=(11)\text{\emph{~{}~{}i.e.} if~{}~{}}N_{2}\equiv N_{4}.\end{matrix}

    It follows that 𝐱∈A​(1+3​i)T𝐱𝐴superscript13𝑖𝑇\mathbf{x}\in A(1+3i)^{T} only if N2≢N4not-equivalent-tosubscript𝑁2subscript𝑁4N_{2}\not\equiv N_{4} and T𝑇T is odd. Clearly, these conditions are different to those to the previous two cases and therefore no ambiguities exist.
